p: The methanol extracts of the eight plants that showed antibacterial activity were further tested for biofilm inhibitory activity against S. aureus. The ability of the extracts to considerably inhibit biofilm formation by a strong biofilm producer (i.e., S. aureus) was determined and the minimum biofilm inhibitory concentration (MBIC) recorded. From the experiments, six out of the eight plant extracts failed to significantly inhibit biofilm formation by S. aureus at concentrations up to 10 mg/mL ( Figure 4(a)– 4(b)). Meanwhile, the methanol extracts of two plants, Grossera vignei (MGV) and Holarrhena floribunda (MHF), showed appreciable biofilm formation inhibitory activities. At a concentration of 1.25 mg/mL, MHF reduced S. aureus from a high biofilm producer (OD > 1.38) to a low biofilm-producing organism with an OD < 0.24 ( Figure 4(b)). G. vignei, methanol extract (MGV) on the other hand, reduced the biofilm production of S. aureus to a moderate biofilm producer at concentrations of 5 to 10 mg/mL ( Figure 4(b)).
